metadata.name: The Past Ahead #229
metadata.description:
Cyanotypes once were the most advanced technology to create images. When I see one today I look at it as a beautiful relic and I can't help but put my present in perspective. In these uncertain times the technologies we use to create are threatened with sudden extinction. But I feel joy in imagining our works joining the strata of history, a fallen species, the breeding ground of creations to come.

Controls :

• Press 1, 2, 3, or 4 to make a capture and download a PNG with a resolution of x1, x2, x3 or x4.

———————

The Past Ahead by Ferdinand Dervieux, 2022
Made with Unity
License: CC BY-NC-SA 4.0

metadata.name: Faux #235
metadata.description:
This project is borne out of my longstanding fascination with brushwork, and the intricate textures that can be created with a brush, some paint and a canvas. Brush strokes are simulated using many overlapping lines and given texture and depth using a custom shader. Another important aspect of this work, is the composite forms that are created by the brush strokes, which are my attempt to emulate the emphatic energy of many abstract painters that have come before me. Color palettes are named after common paint colors, based on the background color used for the palette.

Those who collect during the first tier of the Dutch Auction can claim a signed print. They will be printed on A3 Hahnemuhle Photo Rag, and shipped to the collector free of charge. More details on how to claim a print and specify the necessary shipping information will be provided via the artists twitter (@landlinesart1).

In live mode, add &size=<YOUR_PIXEL_SIZE> to change the pixel size of the image for export (Right click to save). For example, &size=4000 will set the width of the image to be 4000 pixels.

metadata.name: Blotto! #86
metadata.description:
Vanilla JS + SVG
November 2022

Edition of 365

The starting point for this piece was an attempt to simulate the effect of dropping coloured inks or paints onto wet or dry paper ("blots") by combining mixed gradients and various levels of svg filters. I then added stroke and fine line drawings to the blots and played around with rotation and opacity and leaving blanks in the grids. 

The results range from minimal smooth circles, sometimes fading away into the background, to noisy splashes or clouds.

The defined features of the project are:

Blot palettes: 9+n (1 is generated randomly)
Blotting paper: 6 colours
Blot grid: 5 layouts (1x1, 3x3, 5x5, 10x10, 20x20)
Blot stroke: true/false
Blot blanks: true/false
Blotted lines: true/false
Blotulence! (extra turbulence): true/false

To save a PNG file, press "P" or save an SVG by pressing "S"

This project has been tested and works in Chrome, Brave, Edge and Firefox (a little slower on the latter, so please be patient). It does not work in Safari or on IOS at this time.

// PRIMARY SALES
If/when the project mints out, 50% of primary will be donated to Girls Who Code Canada (https://girlswhocode.com/en-ca) and the other 50% to Breakfast Club Canada and I will post the donation receipts on the fx(hash) Discord as well as on my Twitter & genart.social.

metadata.name: d/e/m/boss TWO #156
metadata.description:
TWO combines a couple of distribution algorithms, one that creates a mesh with different variations and the other that plays with packing probabilities.

Please be patient, it takes a while to render (30-60 secs) and draws around 6M circles during 4 steps.

Responsive, zoom out browser window and refresh to get a larger output.
's' save the current canvas

TWO is part of a series playing with textures creating emboss/deboss effect.

de/
/boss
em/

100% code, made with p5js
See License.md

metadata.name: A Distant Memory #184
metadata.description:
A distant memory of trees, buildings and the old village. Once a moment, the memory is illuminated by a beam of light, which gives me the insight of this work.

--------------------

This is an abstract generation made by pure code.

--------------------

In live mode, press 's' or 'S' to save a high resolution png.

Please be patient with drawing process (it'll take one minute in my computer).
This is my last artwork in 2022. I hope you like this work.

Endlessworld 2022

metadata.name: Circumscript #36
metadata.description:
It has always been a goal of mine to incorporate the worlds of physical and digital art together in a piece. And with circumscript I am the closest I've ever been. Circumscript uses a custom shader written to mix and "dilute" the colors on the canvas, thus creating a very physical feeling piece.

This dilution can be more or less depending on the edition, but always plays a huge role in the feel of the piece.


Happy new year.


----


[m] or [double tap] : opens the export/settings menu, use this menu to change the resolution, and make sure to press the reload button if you do.
[holding down] : zooms in on a certain area of the piece, depending on where your mouse/finger is. Use this feature to expore the complex textures of the piece in more detail, it's highly recommended to do this on a higher resolution setting.

The outputs can vary slighty per device, as there's a slight difference in how certain math gets interpreted on different devices with shaders.


----


Made with p5.js and webgl by Wouter Missler in 2022/3.

metadata.name: caravans #295
metadata.description:
This piece is inspired by Paul Klee's 'Zwei Kamele und ein Esel' (Two camels and a donkey), abacuses and excessive shopping sprees.

An anonymous caravan makes its way through abstract deserts, carrying their semi-brutalist cargo towards an unknown destination.

All primary proceeds go to the Processing foundation.

Happy birthday fxhash!

Written in JavaScript, rendering to Canvas.

metadata.name: Diaphanous Sprouts  #5
metadata.description:
Particle painting exploration.

p -> screen capture

Built w p5.js, TypeScript, Protobyte.js, Node, Parcel

Thanks Robin, Ian, Sophie

metadata.name: Meditating Lines #33
metadata.description: A calming meditative piece with smooth movement and a couple of moments of illumination.

metadata.name: Scalabili-TREE  #31
metadata.description:
Scalabili-TREE 
Growing up and adapting to the world!

For the Decentralized Autonomous Education (https://linktr.ee/cubiclearn) (DAE) project they asked me to represent the concept of "scalability" with an artwork.
Scalability is one of the ten principles on which the DAE project is based. The other nine principles were represented by nine other artists.

To represent the concept of scalability in a visual way, with a generative algorithm, I was inspired by nature and plants.
I represented this concept through the growth rings of trees, drawing shapes that evoked the section of a cut tree. Each ring represents the growth of the tree and its ability to adapt to the environment while continuing to function efficiently.
This can involve a variety of different strategies, for example the tree can increase root depth and branch out to support a larger canopy, or develop mechanisms to conserve water and nutrients to survive in a dry environment
One key aspect of scalability in trees is the ability to adapt to changing environmental conditions over time.

The work was created through the construction of a generative algorithm that designs each ring starting from the center, gradually adding the outer layers, exactly as the tree itself would do.

Everything is generated with code.
This work uses p5.js library and c2.js library.

metadata.name: Terraced #56
metadata.description:
terraced craters
towering mountains
tranquil colors
dimetric

* this is an animated artwork, the animation loops, its duration depends on the piece, it can be paused by pressing 'p'
* this is a somewhat interactive artwork, click and drag to rotate around/above the object, scroll to zoom in/out
* the current view can be downloaded by pressing 'd'

I began exploring terraced reliefs 3 years ago, starting with lines and cellular noise, and eventually flat colors that turned into subtle gradients.
During that time, the visual concept oscillated between minimalism and busy images. I dropped the cellular noise, replacing it with 2D simplex noise modifying points on the dual grid.
The result is finally something that produces the iterations that keep me happy, something soothing and quiet. Spend some time with it, see how the light changes the landscape.

Best viewed in landscape mode, 3/2 or 16/9.
